Form Responses 1.Title: Erase All Kittens
Form Responses 1.Description: An online platform game that teaches youth to code and create on the web.
Interest: It's fun because you hack the game levels
writting HTML and CSS in order to complete the game.

Form Responses 1.Title: Neurostars.org
Form Responses 1.Description: NeuroStars is an experiment to engage the neuroinformatics community in a question & answer site tailored to their subject area.

Form Responses 1.Title: Biosurveillance using Social Media
Form Responses 1.Description: A project to visualize social media data used in an early detection system for disease epidemics as they emerge.

Form Responses 1.Title: Flyweb
Form Responses 1.Description: Webpages as server and more.

Form Responses 1.Title: Pixel Racer
Form Responses 1.Description: A game of pixels racing and stuff.

Form Responses 1.Title: Software Discovery Dashboard
Description: We are creating an open source web dashboard capable of searching multiple code hosting services
such as Zenodo
Figshare
and GitHub
for the benefit of the research community.

Form Responses 1.Title: Webmaker Android
Description: Webmaker enables people to discover
create
and share rich content from their mobile device.
Interest: It brings some of the web’s best features to a mobile app
going beyond a soundbite or photo filter enabling truly creative projects.

Form Responses 1.Title: html-o-matic
Form Responses 1.Description: A tool for exploring CSS styles with a fun shuffle interface.
Form Responses 1.Interest: It's a simple way to accidentally learn about CSS.

Form Responses 1.Title: Bezier JS
Form Responses 1.Description: A javascript library for working with Bezier curves.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Drawing curves with code is complicated. This  much easier draw them and understand how they work!

Form Responses 1.Title: Ride w/ Me
Form Responses 1.Description: A peer-to-peer transportation solution for youth.
Interest: Built by youth
for youth
this app helps them find a peer to travel with to school and after-school programs.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: See information on the website.

Form Responses 1.Title: Flexbox Froggy
Form Responses 1.Description: Flexbox Froggy is a game for learning CSS flexbox.
Interest: Fun way to learn how to format web content. Takes inspiration from the games Frogger
CSS Diner and Erase all Kittens.

Form Responses 1.Title: Hour of Design
Form Responses 1.Description: A video series with live UI design.
Form Responses 1.Interest: This can help demystify the process of design and share how even the most beautiful designs always start with a blank canvas.

Form Responses 1.Title: Pontoon
Description: Pontoon allows you to localize web content in place
with context and spatial limitations right in front of you.
Form Responses 1.Interest: It simplifies localization for site owners and volunteers. Localization makes a more inclusive web for everyone.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: See website to add it to your site or contribute toward development.

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla Stumbler
Form Responses 1.Description: Location Services is a tool to find user locations from nearby cell towers & WiFi signals. Stumbler is an app for contributing data.
Interest: This is an open-source
privacy-minded alternative to Google and other location services.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Download the app to contribrute to the pool of shared data.

Form Responses 1.Title: Winners and Losers in the Global App Economy
Description: A research report to look deeper at the global trends in app revenue flow
with a particularly lens on emerging markets.
Interest: Research was supported by Mozilla Foundation
and maps to our goals around digital inclusion
and many other points in the Mozilla Mission.

Form Responses 1.Title: Trust
Form Responses 1.Description: A tool for blog or news publishers to use existing comments to indicate trust or reputation of people who comment.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Comments are tricky and volatile. This helps publishers find & highlight their best commenters so they can set tone for future visitors.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to the community dialog or the code. Start at https://coralproject.net/get-involved/.
Network connection: The Coral Project is a collaboration between the Mozilla Foundation
and is funded by a grant from the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation.

Form Responses 1.Title: Census Reporter
Form Responses 1.Description: Make it easy for journalists to write stories using US Census data.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Simplifies finding and using data from the United States decennial census and the American Community Survey.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Knight News Challenge-funded project. Ryan Pitts sits on the board of the project.

Form Responses 1.Title: Tabula
Form Responses 1.Description: A tool for liberating data tables locked inside PDF files.
Interest: currently in use at ProPublica
the Times of London
Foreign Policy
La Nación
and the St. Paul Pioneer Press
among many others
from
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute via https://github.com/tabulapdf/tabula
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Created by OpenNews fellows Manuel Aristarán and Mike Tigas and the New York Times' Jeremy B. Merrill.

Form Responses 1.Title: Unveillance
Description: Privately send documents to a server to run bits of code experiments
written by you or your friends.
Interest: A library that combines friend-to-friend file sharing
machine learning
and If-This-Then-That-style programming.
Network connection: A recipient of a Knight Prototype grant
from former Open News fellow Harlo Holmes.

Form Responses 1.Title: NewsLynx
Form Responses 1.Description: A tool for measuring the qualitative and quantitative impact of news stories.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Enables journalists and publishers to measure the impact of their stories.
Network connection: Had an official launch at SRCCON 2015
from former fellow Brian Abelson and Al Jazeera America’s Michael Keller.

Form Responses 1.Title: Command-line bootcamp
Form Responses 1.Description: An "interactive adventure" to learn the UNIX command line in the browser.

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozfest Schedule App
Description: It's a mobile-friendly web app that allows MozFest staff to easily update the official schedule of sessions
panels
activities
etc.
Interest: It's open source
original used for SRCCON
so can be adapted to other in-person events with lots of programmatic offerings.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to the code. Fork it for your own event.
Network connection: Was created specifically to support MozFest
and based on code used to support SRCCON

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla Foundation Research Blog
Form Responses 1.Description: A blog from the research team in the field.
Interest: Interesting insights on how real people view
connect with
and use the internet.

Form Responses 1.Title: Cards Against Community
Form Responses 1.Description: A card game about online communities.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Online communities work in complex ways. Game helps open a conversation with any group on how they work and can evolve.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Download the card artwork and help improve the cards.
Form Responses 1.Suggestions & Feedback: Would be nice to notify the creator when a thing is added.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Made by the Mozilla funded Coral Project to help expand range of people who can contribute to their work.

Form Responses 1.Title: Agate
Description: A tool that helps you analyze data
optimized for humans instead of machines.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Solve real-world problems with readable code.
Get involved: with a lot of issues to choose from. https://github.com/wireservice/agate/issues
Network connection: This library was created by a developer in the journalism-code community
and has been adopted rapidly by journalist/developers. We published an introductory piece on Source and have helped to spread the word.

Form Responses 1.Title: SMS Vote Updater
Form Responses 1.Description: This is a service that texts you when your legislator votes in congress.
Form Responses 1.Interest: It makes easy to keep track of real political action.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Tennyson Holloway and Public Knowledge participated in the Ford-Mozilla Open Web Fellows Program.

Form Responses 1.Title: What can I do for the Internet
Description: A fun and easy thing you can do each week
sent by email.
Interest: It's fun
easy
and productive.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Tennyson Holloway and Public Knowledge participated in the Ford-Mozilla Open Web Fellows Program.

Form Responses 1.Title: NetPosi
Form Responses 1.Description:
A podcast about 
activism & technology.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Interviews with technologists making a mark in the world of activism (or vice versa). Guests include Cory Doctorow and Wendy Seltzer.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Have an idea about a topic or guest for an episode? Email: info@netposi.com.

Form Responses 1.Title: Urban CO2
Description: An interactive web app to communicate the importance of cities as sources of CO2 emissions
using mobile sensors.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Cool way to engage with environmental sensors and understand/compare urban environments.
Get involved: Add an issue to the repo
or check back for more documentation and CONTRIBUTING.md updates as the project matures.
Suggestions & Feedback: I think all the questions are necessary
maybe break it up with some bullet point questions
like choose 3 tags that best describe this project from a controlled vocabulary of 10
that would give you some fun sorting possibilities later. I guess it's auto-collected
but the first commit date or the date of project initiation might be interesting to request
as it will differ from the timestamp hrere.
Network connection: Joey is a Mozilla Science Fellow
part of the 2015 Mozilla Science Lab cohort.

Form Responses 1.Title: Slidewinder
Description: Instant
beautiful
pick-and-mix slide decks.
Interest: Everyone gives talks and wants to re-use slides or remix old decs
or share decs with others.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Richard is one of the Mozilla Science Fellows 2015 cohort.

Form Responses 1.Title: Network Pulse
Form Responses 1.Description: A stream of things made by peers in our network.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Submit your project. Share the love and find collaborators.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Submit projects by you and others to this site. Submit ideas and bugs via github.
Form Responses 1.Origin: Our distributed network includes lots of innovative projects that lack visibility. This initiative aims to unlock all those good things.

Form Responses 1.Title: Together JS
Form Responses 1.Description: TogetherJS is a service for your website that makes it easy for your users to collaborate in real-time.

Form Responses 1.Title: The Ghanta Project
Form Responses 1.Description: The 'Ghanta' or bell that serves as a call to gather as a community. It's an IoT connected product: a bell and a tablet.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Physical prototype with web interaction
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Ring the bell.
Suggestions & Feedback: Include ability to add more collaborators. Would be nice to have longer project description option -- it's ok to cut down to 140 characters
but an  Expand  view would be good so we can say more. The Helpful Info questions were a bit confusing -- not sure what you wanted to hear.

Form Responses 1.Title: Conductive Contracts
Description: Complete the circuit by stamping it. Yourcontractisdigitallyauthorizedusingconductiveink
Indian stamp paper
& your thumbprint.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Exploring conductive ink

Form Responses 1.Title: Code of Conduct builder
Form Responses 1.Description: An online tool for building a thorough and well-supported Code of Conduct specific to a community's online and/or offline environment.
Form Responses 1.Interest: The challenge to write and support a code of conduct and healthy community is shared by many people.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Gem Barrett is a Ford-Mozilla Open Web Fellow.

Title: Jumpstart: Pop-Ups
Hack Jams & Maker Parties
Description: This two-pager provides an overview on using pop-ups
hack jams and maker parties to promote youth pathways and organizational innovation.
Interest: Anyone running pop-ups
hack-jams or maker parties can up their game in terms of how youth and organizations benefit from these events.
Get involved: If you used recommendations from the jumpstart
we'd love to hear how they played out!
Network connection: Lots of organizations in Hive networks and in the broader Mozilla world run pop-ups
which is what inspired us to make this Jumpstart.

Form Responses 1.Title: Alphabet Typer Race
Form Responses 1.Description: Type the alphabet as fast as you can!
Form Responses 1.Interest: They like to type fast.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: They can try to type the alphabet as fast as they can.

Form Responses 1.Title: Teaching Kit: Combating Cyber Violence Against Women & Girls
Description: Teaching kit provides understanding of cyber violence against women & girls
creating safer places online
recognizing bullying/attacks.
Interest: For the internet to remain an open & safe place
we need to understand why & how cyber violence occurs to step in and prevent it.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Join the discussion on the forum and share your stories.

Form Responses 1.Title: New Ways to Connect To Mozilla Learning
Description: Mozilla Learning now offers a newsletter
curriculum workshop
community call
and Tweetchat as regular
monthly ways to connect.
Interest: Strengthen relationships with our community
to support & provide open/free resources
and create spaces to connect people across the globe.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Tweet @MozTeach or email teachtheweb@mozillafoundation.org with questions/feedback.
Form Responses 1.Origin: Streamline communications to community throughout Mozilla Learning Team.

Form Responses 1.Title: SPARK Hackathon
Description: Participants came from six different area high schools and formed teams to tackle real-world problems posed by sponsors
including Mozilla.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Local industry professionals came to HS students with real-life problems to solve.

Form Responses 1.Title: Web Literacy Basics I Localization Project
Form Responses 1.Description: Heavily community-completed project of localizing teaching kit Web Literacy Basics I.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Over 20+ contributors translated Web Literacy Basics I into 10 languages.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: If you are interested in translating curriculum contact teachtheweb@mozillafoundation.org.
Form Responses 1.Origin: This is the 1st activity to be offered in other languages besides English!

Form Responses 1.Title: How Can South Africa Kickstart Its Tech Industry?
Description: When two reporters with The Atlantic set out to explore internet education and innovation in South Africa
Mozilla weighed in as an expert.
Interest: Mozilla sounds off on web literacy
Mozilla Learning
and our read
write
participate philosophy.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Mozilla and Executive Director Mark Surman quoted in the article.

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla's Web Literacy Map Teaches the Essential Web Skills Everyone Should Know
Form Responses 1.Description: Story about Mozilla in Lifehacker
Form Responses 1.Interest: Mozilla in the news!

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla made a game to teach you the basics of encryption
Form Responses 1.Description: Engadget coverage of Mozilla's Codemoji game

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla expands its National Gigabit Project to Austin
Form Responses 1.Description: Coverage of Mozilla's gigabit work
Form Responses 1.Interest: Mozilla in the news

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla Foundation Backs Apple In Encryption Case With Federal Government
Form Responses 1.Description: Coverage of Mozilla's encryption campaign
Form Responses 1.Interest: Mozilla in the news

Form Responses 1.Title: Codemoji
Description: A fun
interactive tool to learn about ciphers and the importance of encryption.
Form Responses 1.Interest: It's fun! You can send coded messages to your friends and family.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Send a coded message and share Codemoji with your friends!

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla Clubs end of year goals: 2016
Form Responses 1.Description: A description of goals for Mozilla Clubs for the remainder of 2016
Form Responses 1.Interest: It is an update on Mozilla clubs
Form Responses 1.Suggestions & Feedback: I would like to see a date and location for the projects listed. I also wish there were a drop down menu of tags we could pull from.

Form Responses 1.Title: Tumbleweed
Form Responses 1.Description: Origami artist developed paper prototypes of folding robots that could repair damaged rovers on Mars. Final five winner in NASA challenge.
Form Responses 1.Network connection: Robby pitched this project during the Brooklyn Space Apps / Science Hack Day that the Mozilla Science Lab hosted in 2016.

Form Responses 1.Title: Network Pulse Launch (testing!)
Form Responses 1.Description: We're launching network pulse
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Code?

Form Responses 1.Title: Network Demos
Description: 5 Aug 2016 – Demos of our recent projects
including design
engineering
and related programs.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Fast forward to specific projects: 0:56 networking mapping. 8:20 MozFest design. 14:20 Pulse. 19:52 Mentorship program. 21:10 Site localization. 23:30 Carousel component.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Join us to watch or share a demo. Usually runs twice a month on Friday 10am Pacific.

Form Responses 1.Title: Interview: Robby Kraft on NASA Challenge
Form Responses 1.Description: Mozilla interviewed origami artist developed paper prototypes of folding robots that could repair damaged rovers on Mars. Final five winner in NASA challenge.
Form Responses 1.Interest: An unexpected story about a network member that brings art and paper prototypes to the design of robot for Mars.
Form Responses 1.Origin: Science Hack Day that the Mozilla Science Lab hosted

Form Responses 1.Title: Mentorship Program
Form Responses 1.Description: 12 week online mentorship program designed to connect open leaders and increase collaboration and contributorship on open projects in our network.

Form Responses 1.Title: Too Poor to Afford the Internet
Form Responses 1.Description: Article by NYPL President Tony Marx’s (Hive NYC member) in the NY Times OpEd on digital inclusion.
Interest: Strong framing for the issues
problems and opportunities we face insuring that the public internet is protected.

Form Responses 1.Title: Science Lab Community Call - August 2016
Description: Notes from the Mozilla Science Lab's August community call on maps and mapped data. This call takes place every other month
highlighting work relevant to science and the web.

Form Responses 1.Title: Women and Web Literacy Website
Form Responses 1.Description: Information and resources related to the Women and Web literacy initiative.

Form Responses 1.Title: Network Demos
Description: 2 Sep 2016 – Demos of the new Women and Web Lit site (1:35) and Gigabit site integration (21:35). Three Mozfest updates: network mapping tools (5:45)
schedule app (13:20)
and style guide (17:10).
Form Responses 1.Interest: An open look at what we make and how we make.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Everyone is welcome to join the video call.

Form Responses 1.Title: Power and Empowerment on the Internet
Form Responses 1.Description: Mark Surman reflects on the internet freedom movement in the age of empires.
Interest: Despite monopolies
walled gardens
and surveillance on the internet
there's a grassroots movement for online freedom
creativity and opportunity for all.

Form Responses 1.Title: DreamYard Learning Portfolio
Form Responses 1.Description: A project to bring the Learning Portfolio model to schools and educational organization across NYC by making the digital portfolios more accessible to all students to tell their own learning story.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Supported by the New York Community Trust’s Hive Digital Media and Learning Fund
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Interested in bringing Learning Portfolios to your school or organizations?

Form Responses 1.Title: New York City Haunts
Form Responses 1.Description: Integrating local history and social issues into geo-locative game design.
Interest: First Lady Michelle Obama played this game! NYC Haunts is a STEM-based learning program in which youth designers create a mobile
geo-locative alternate reality game that explores local history and contemporary issues facing a particular NYC neighborhood.

Form Responses 1.Title: Radio Rookies Toolkit
Form Responses 1.Description: An animated series to teach teenagers how to create in-depth audio documentaries about their lives and communities.
Interest: In partnership with Hive NYC
Radio Rookies worked with animator Masayoshi Nakamura to create a DIY Radio Rookies Toolkit. The toolkit is a series of engaging resources including four animated shorts
all embedded within a digital comic book
“The Making of a Radio Rookies Story.”

Form Responses 1.Title: Designing safe and inclusive events for women
Form Responses 1.Description: Some best practices on how to design safe and inclusive events for women and girls.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Email your best practices to womenandweb@mozillafoundation.org

Form Responses 1.Title: Github Shout-out
Description: Github's 2016 report on the state of open source code highlights Mozilla's @acabunoc
developing new ways to engage contributors.
Form Responses 1.Interest: The report details interesting trends on open and social software development. Shoutout to Abby demonstrates the importance of engagement to foster healthy and productive software projects.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Check out Abby's mentorship program.
Form Responses 1.Suggestions & Feedback: mw: I'm curious if people will think this fits the scope of Pulse.

Form Responses 1.Title: Copyright Petition
Form Responses 1.Description: Sign and share our copyright petition
Form Responses 1.Interest: Copyright laws impact a lot of our everyday activities
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Sign the petition and share

Form Responses 1.Title: Merits of Thimble
Description: Hacker News community discuss Thimble and how it compares to other online coding tools for demos
learning
and mentorship. Localized
open source
and with a built-in tutorial feature.
Interest: It's interesting to hear how people who might not be connected to the open web or web literacy movements
view this tool.
Get involved: or contribute to the project's development via Github.

Form Responses 1.Title: Open Innovation Toolkit
Description: Toolkit helps you incorporate human-centered design into open source product development. Whether you have a new idea or a working prototype to test
there's lots of info here to help.
Interest: Contains lots of helpful tips on how to gather insights
ideate
prototype and test. Helps you avoid common pitfalls and stay on a path toward success.

Form Responses 1.Title: Thimble
Description: Thimble is an online code editor that makes it easy to create and publish your own web pages while learning HTML
CSS & JavaScript.

Form Responses 1.Title: Open Project Communication
Form Responses 1.Description: Handout for creating a useful and welcoming readme file for your open project. Use at the Working Open Workshop.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this document in GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: Introduction to Roadmapping
Form Responses 1.Description: This activity is designed to help you write a Roadmap for your open source project or study group. Used at the Working Open Workshop.
Form Responses 1.Interest: This can help you write a roadmap for your project
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this doc via GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: Wrangling Web Contributions
Form Responses 1.Description: In this activity you will learn how to create and maintain a CONTRIBUTING.md for an open source project. Used at the Working Open Workshop.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Help writing contributor guidelines when you're starting a new open source project
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this document on GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: GitHub for Collaboration on Open Projects
Form Responses 1.Description: Get comfortable with a Collaborative workflow in the GitHub interface. Used at the Working Open Workshop.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this guide on GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: Getting Started with Codes of Conduct
Description: This activity walks you through some considerations associated with anti-harassment policies
and help you put in place a plan and process for creating a welcoming
inclusive
harrassment-free space.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Help writing a code of conduct
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this guide via GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: Running Sprints and Community Events
Form Responses 1.Creators: Mozilla Science Lab and Madeleine Bonsma
Form Responses 1.Description: This activity is designed to get you started on the planning for your first sprint or community event. Used at the Working Open Workshop.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Help organizing a community event
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this guide on GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: Personas and Pathways for Growing Communities
Description: This activity is designed to help you identify potential users and contributors
understand their goals and motivations
help them join your project
and grow them into strong community members.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Help thinking about your community
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this guide on GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: Your Data Can Live Forever: How to Plan for Data Reuse
Form Responses 1.Description: This activity is designed to help you understand what someone outside your research project (or you in 5-10 years) would need to know about your data in order to build on your work.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Help writing a data reuse plan when you're using data
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Contribute to this guide on GitHub

Form Responses 1.Title: Viator VR
Description: Foreign language learning is most effective when it's immersive
but not everyone can study abroad. This virtual reality tech aims to create immersive language learning environments for everyone.
Form Responses 1.Interest: This Mozilla Gigabit funded project explores emerging technology to transcend the boundaries in education.

Form Responses 1.Title: Pennez
Form Responses 1.Description: A hub for multicultural books that now leverages text-to-speech-to-text tech with children's voices to provide real-time feedback for young readers.
Form Responses 1.Interest: This initiative aims to increase literary inclusion by improving reading fluency.

Form Responses 1.Title: The Wayback Machine
Form Responses 1.Description: A prototype product which controls the availability of tech & services within a connected home. Turn a rotary dial to wind back time and turn off digital services and connections.
Interest: The prototype was created during the 2016 Mozilla Open IoT Design Sprint. As a conceptual prototype
it challenges us to think about the control we have over our technology
and the control that tech has over us.

Form Responses 1.Title: Hive Austin's First Meetup
Creators: Portfolio Strategist Hive Austin with support from Google Fiber Austin
Description: Hive ATX's first official meetup on 9/24: a Gigabit Fund info session
EdTech Demo
and networking event for educators
technologists and entrepreneurs interested in digital literacy and inclusion.
Interest: MLN messaging in deck
event agenda and feedback survey; results: most participants came b/c they were invited by someone else
100% wld recommend the event to a colleague & 92% wanted to attend a follow-up meetup in Nov/Dec.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: We're looking for resources that support more inclusive practices in digital literacy education.
Form Responses 1.Suggestions & Feedback: Would be nice to be able to share several links here and/or supporting social media posts.

Form Responses 1.Title: Network Demos
Description: 30 Sept 2016 – Demos of our recent projects. Fast forward to 0:25 to see some MozFest design and production. At 4:10
see the design for the Regional Coordinator bios page for Mozilla Clubs.
Form Responses 1.Interest: An open look at what we make and how we make it.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Join us to watch or share a demo. Usually runs twice a month on Friday 10am Pacific.

Form Responses 1.Title: Postcrimes
Description: In some European Union countries
photographing landmarks and posting the pictures on social media can be illegal. This campaign fights this absurdity.
Interest: This is a fun
innovative way to disrupt foolish public policy.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Learn more and participate in this campaign to change copyright.

Form Responses 1.Title: A Rad Contribution to Thimble
Form Responses 1.Interest: It's a great example of a collaboration with a new contributor

Form Responses 1.Title: MINECRAFT CHALLENGE: Redesign A Public Space
Creators: member of the Hive Chicago Learning Network
Form Responses 1.Description: Make a great public space in Minecraft. This challenge is to design a space that promotes social interaction and a sense of community.
Form Responses 1.Interest: A fun way to explore the dynamics of civic spaces in an active and interactive way. Try on Thimble here: https://thimbleprojects.org/ginagrant/95757/#overview
Form Responses 1.Get involved: https://www.discoverdesign.org/help
Form Responses 1.Suggestions & Feedback: Can you add a field for submitting the url of a featured image?

Form Responses 1.Title: Create Your Own Google Photosphere
Form Responses 1.Description: Hive Chicago member Peggy Notebaert Nature Museum shared their use of photospheres with teens to create immersive 3-D images that empower Internet image creators.
Interest: Anyone who wants to use immersive
360-degree images for place-based learning. Geojournalism.org (http://geojournalism.org/about/) is part of the portfolio of InfoAmazonia (http://infoamazonia.org/)

a multidisciplinary team hosted in Brazil  working to create useful applications for environmental coverage. The online toolkit was created in partnership with Internews’ Earth Journalism Network (http://earthjournalism.net/) and the Flag It! Project (http://ecolab.oeco.org.br/projects/flagit/).

Form Responses 1.Title: PROject US
Description: Inpoints (http://inpoints.org/) is proud to present a special series on PROject US
a fashion
music
and media program in Chicago – Learning to Make and Make It
Interest: PROjectUS (http://www.pro-jectus.org/) is an initiative for young adults between the ages of 13 – 23 designed to build fashion design
music production
and new media journalism skills.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Learn more by visiting the Hive Chicago portfolio page.

Form Responses 1.Title: Celebrating ChiTeen Lit Fest
Form Responses 1.Description: Chicago’s first literary festival for teens by teens. A collaboration of Hive Chicago Learning Network organizations.  Here's a recap.
Interest: The Chicago Teen Lit Fest aims to provide a safe and creative space for young adults to unlock and discover their unique voice through literary arts. The ChiTeen Lit Fest (https://chiteenlitfest.org/) is brought to you by Chicago Public Library
Columbia College Chicago
Poetry Foundation
UIC-College of Education
After School Matters
Center for College Access and Success
Allstate
Jewel Catering
Chicago Tribune

Form Responses 1.Title: CryptoHarlem
Description: Motherboard published an interview with Matt Mitchell
a Mozilla Open Web Fellow. He shares valuable and candid insight on privacy education and making it more inclusive.
Interest: Matt is a security researcher and data journalist who leads CryptoHarlem
teaching basic cryptography tools to the predominately African American community in upper Manhattan.
Get involved: Matt trains activists & journalists in digital security
focused on marginalized populations often aggressively monitored & disenfranchised. His fellowship is based at Color of Change.

Form Responses 1.Title: A Meme Is Born
Form Responses 1.Description: Why we need copyright laws that set the imagination free
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Join the change copyright campaign.

Form Responses 1.Title: CSI:GIF
Form Responses 1.Description: Meet the cops who patrol the tubes of the Internet for the baddest crime of all: GIFs
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Join the campaign behind CSI:GIF jail.

Form Responses 1.Title: Meme Jail
Form Responses 1.Description: See what happens when classic memes head to Europe
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Join the campaign behind meme jail.

Form Responses 1.Title: Crowd2Map Tanzania crowdsourced mapping
Description: Our project uses crowdsourcing to map rural Tanzania
thus improving the development in the region and fighting for important causes
such as ending female genital mutilation (FGM).
Form Responses 1.Interest: This is an opportunity for everyone to contribute to world improvement by doing something fun.
Get involved: People can find all the relevant info through our website and our GitHub repo. People can do mapping
and many other things to help.

Form Responses 1.Title: phageParser
Description: A project to extract
analyze
and share CRISPR information from open genetic data.
Interest: CRISPR research is becoming increasingly popular
and through this project anyone can help make relevant information easier to find and use.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Read about the project and how you can contribute with code or documentation on the GitHub repo!

Form Responses 1.Title: Open Student Book
Form Responses 1.Description: This project would help the Students Community Open Source oriented to grow
Form Responses 1.Get involved: The people can support us making know and helping us to involve it

Form Responses 1.Title: Digital Maker Collective
Description: The Digital Maker Collective are an open group of University of the Arts London staff
students
alumni who share common goals of exploring digital & emerging technologies in the context of arts
education
society and the creative industries.
Interest: Creativity
arts
art school
arts education
creative industries
design
performance
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Join our networks and get involved in upcoming events and meet-ups @CCWDigital #DigitalMakerCollective

Form Responses 1.Title: Figure Canvas
Form Responses 1.Description: A tool for scientists to report repeats of experiments
Form Responses 1.Interest: experimental data is more and more important with an increasingly data driven lifestyle; we ask how real is the data?

Form Responses 1.Title: KORUZA Light-Speed Internet
Form Responses 1.Description: Koruza is a wireless internet system transmitting 1/10 GB of data  through a beam of light from building to building up to 150m apart.
Interest: Instead of expensive cables or congested radio waves
Koruza transceivers connect with a beam of light. Set-up in hours
not days and connecting buildings up to 150 metres apart at 10 Gbps
Koruza transceivers are ten times cheaper than other optical connectors.
Get involved: Koruza is developed open source and open hardware. It is available for preorder from October 2016 on. Order a kit

Form Responses 1.Title: Video Game Puppetry
Form Responses 1.Description: See how EK Theater uses video games in their unique form of puppetry
Form Responses 1.Interest: EK Theater's work has been called "an impressive feat of engineering, coordination, and storytelling" by the New York Times. Learn their innovative techniques with director Eddie Kim!

Form Responses 1.Title: A-Painter
Description: Virtual Reality Painting on the Web. Put on the headset and let your creative spirit loose in an infinite and unconstrained space
expressing yourself visually with A-Painter from Mozilla
a virtual reality painting experience delivered through WebVR.
Interest: Digital artists and VR enthusiasts will both love creative freedom that web-scale extensibility brings to creative tools
and everyone will enjoy the unrestricted creative expression that A-Painter enables!
Get involved: A-Frame and A-Painter. Build and share custom brushes for A-Painter! Liquid fire
or let a million flowers bloom with a wave of your hand!

Form Responses 1.Title: Music Box
Form Responses 1.Description: Music Box began in Detroit as a way for long-time residents to share stories and preserve the history of their rapidly gentrifying neighborhoods. We are currently widening to expand it to other neighborhoods and innovate in the way we collect stories.
Interest: Music Box provides a way for residents to facilitate community engagement
organizing storytelling events and mobile based storytelling abilities. Participants can share stories and interact with the spaces and histories around them
and new residents and developers can gain local context.
Get involved: Help us to further develop our documentation
host a music box in your neighborhood
or join in the brainstorming and build-out of a story collection kiosk we are working on building!

Form Responses 1.Title: Real-life Open Science workflows
Description: We will look at how Open Science practices can be combined into a full Open Science workflow. We also want to come up with concrete ideas to improve the use and interoperability of Open Science tools
so that scholars and scientists experience less obstacles in using these.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Help increase the uptake of Open Science workflows by removing technical and non-technical issues
Get involved: Come to our session! Saturday 3:15 PM

Form Responses 1.Title: Go Green IoT
Description: Labmet is an open source platform that was built with a simple goal: to help people with agriculture by seamlessly using the agronomical best practices on their own planted food
and to help them lower environmental impact.
Interest: With this project people around the world will minimize water waste
avoid unnecessary pesticides
and reduce environmental contaminates. A simple IoT platform will help them utilize all the agronomic best practices.
Get involved: It would be awesome to have contributors to our project! There is plenty of stuff that the project requires and the community can help such as adding agricultural and agrometeorological models to the labmet libraries

Form Responses 1.Title: Off Grid
Description: Ever wanted to explore data privacy
circumvention technology
and cyber security while playing a game? 'Off Grid' explores these themes through stealth and hacking mechanics and puzzles
and is fully moddable for players to tell their own stories around these important subjects.
Interest: Off Grid is a unique way to explore what can be abstract or opaque issues
and creates a platform for people to tell their own stories about privacy and security through modding the game to make their own levels.
Get involved: who may be interested in modding or creating interesting plays on the game to tell more in depth stories around their area of expertise
or their cultural experience of the themes of privacy and security.

Form Responses 1.Title: #Hacked - Investigate Syria's Cyberwar
Creators: Al Jazeera English & Nataly Rios Goico
Form Responses 1.Description: Syria's Electronic Armies is a mobile web app which takes the user deep into Syria's cyber war.  It's an immersive news experience that presents Al Jazeera's award-winning journalism in a non-fictional game format where the user has to take security based decisions to keep sources safe.

Form Responses 1.Title: Stall Catchers
Form Responses 1.Description: Stall Catchers is a brand new citizen science game. Looking at real blood vessel data you can help speed up the search for Alzheimer's treatments!
Interest: Stall Catchers game empowers everyone to directly fight a disease that affects them
their loved ones and the society at large.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: People can help Alzheimer's research by participating in the game.

Form Responses 1.Title: Hack Brexit
Form Responses 1.Description: A workshop to continue building two open source projects that were originally built during the Hack Brexit hackathon this summer to create positive dialogue and action beyond Brexit.
Interest: Whether you're technical or non technical
voted to leave or remain: Brexit affects us all. The aim of Hack Brexit is to continue to create dialogue and action for a country divided.
Get involved: You can get involved in lots of ways
technical or non technical but we are especially looking for Ruby developers at present. Join our Meetup.

Form Responses 1.Title: CarbonHero
Form Responses 1.Description: CarbonHero is an app that lets people reduce their environmental impact by compensating carbon emissions of their daily activities.
Form Responses 1.Interest: CarbonHero empowers people to take responsibility for their behavior and encourages to take action - either by emitting less or compensating for the activities that can't be avoided.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: We are looking for testers who want to help us refining the offering. Additionally let us know if you want to connect your service to ours or if we can exchange data.

Form Responses 1.Title: Localization Lab
Description: Localization Lab is a network of over 5
000 developers and volunteer translators collaborating to localize Internet freedom tools: technology that addresses security
privacy
anonymity
whistleblowing
circumvention issues
including training materials to support these tools.
Interest: The projects that our community works on are open source technologies that help offer access to the open Internet to people around the globe and also help individuals keep their data secure. The encryption
circumvention and anonymity tools are as relevant as ever across all Internet users.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: We are interested in growing our translator community as well as supporting other open source Internet freedom related projects. Let us know if you have a qualifying project or would like to contribute to translations!

Form Responses 1.Title: EveryPolitician
Form Responses 1.Creators: mySociety and @everypolitbot and hundreds of sources around the world
Description: Data about every national legislature in the world
freely available for you to use. Current and historic data. Useful and consistent formats: CSV
JSON
code libraries. Growing all the time.
Interest: We've got 71
933 politicians from 233 countries (so far)... and growing. Useful for parliamentary monitoring orgs.
civic tech coders
journalists
researchers
historians and... citizens!
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Help us by: 1. playing at gender-balance.org    2. telling us about sources we've not got yet   3. using the data to do wonderful things

Form Responses 1.Title: REMEDI Research Access
Description: REMEDI provides medical researchers access to  smart  med device data from hundreds of hospitals
and offers a way for researchers to publish study results in the form of data-driven decision-support tools for the med professionals to use in their daily work to improve patient safety.
Get involved: We are looking to collaborate with open health data and health data privacy experts

Form Responses 1.Title: Citizen-E
Form Responses 1.Description: Citizen-E is a new initiative to create a crowdsourced citizen and government engagement platform on public health and education.

Form Responses 1.Title: Learning Portfolio Builder
Description: The Learning Portfolio Builder is process of MAKING> DOCUMENTING> SELF-REFLECTING> SHARING
both off and online.
Form Responses 1.Interest: It is  a fun and playful way of curating process and final pieces when putting together a portfolio

Form Responses 1.Title: Off The Beat
Form Responses 1.Creators: Helix Arts & Cramlington Voluntary Youth Project
Form Responses 1.Description: We want to jam with you...an experiment between Mozfest London and Northumberland. No music skills needed.
Interest: If interested in digital
latency
live streaming
sharing and collaborating...with a hint of an interest in music
get along. Everyone listens to music
right?!
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Follow @helixarts to support our project.

Form Responses 1.Title: Transformational Profolios: the Wildcat Within
Description: Creating badging projects that exhibit employability skills to future employers
motivate high school students and give back to the community.
Get involved: leaders and more can create badges. Programmers can help with platform design and more.

Title: Nature
In Code
Description: Learn JavaScript while learning biology. Nature
In Code is a web resource
a MOOC and a book
Form Responses 1.Interest: Anyone trying to bring computational thinking using just the browser to students? This project could be interesting for you.

Form Responses 1.Title: Open Cosmics
Form Responses 1.Description: Cosmic-ray physics for everyone!

Form Responses 1.Title: Digital Skills Observatory
Description: Studying the impact of digital skills on people
smartphones
and digital financial services.
Get involved: Becoming an Open Research Volunteer for this project is a great opportunity to learn skills related to research
and technology while providing guidance and leadership for participants and other community members.

Form Responses 1.Title: Cytoscape.js
Form Responses 1.Description: Library written purely in JS for graph theory.
Interest: Cytoscape.js covers both the typical drawing and user interaction usecase as found in apps and also the lower level
algorithmic usecase for analysing graph data.

Form Responses 1.Title: CrowdAI
Form Responses 1.Description: CrowdSourcing the development of Artificial Intelligence - An open challenge platform for data science and Open Science
Interest: Open data challenges on the web give everyone around the world a shot at tackling difficult data problems. By providing their solutions openly
participants can rapidly learn the latest powerful techniques from each other.

Form Responses 1.Title: Swoopi
Form Responses 1.Description: Camera interactions for the Raspberry Pi.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Your contributions are appreciated!

Form Responses 1.Title: Global Advocacy Database
Form Responses 1.Description: An online platform where one can search for information about all advocacy and civil society organizations.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Take a look at the GitHub repo

Form Responses 1.Title: Drilling into new potentials for Open Badges - Mozfest presentation
Description: The opening session at Mozfest
from Mark Surman
raised the question about widening acceptance by industry and organisations. So is security a potential addition to some badges to widen participation and acceptance?
Interest: Increasing the use and acceptability of Open Badges as credentials
new ideas

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla Technology
Form Responses 1.Description: A landing page spotlighting key technologies developed by folks at Mozilla.
Interest: The page demonstrates how Mozilla builds solutions to improve the security of the Internet
champions a web that is open source
and makes systems programming accessible for more programmers.

Form Responses 1.Title: Tips for desinging safe and inclusive events for women and girls
Form Responses 1.Description: The purpose of this guide is to equip event facilitators with the required know-how to ensure effective and impactful event management for women and girls.

Form Responses 1.Title: Teaching Kit: Combatting Cyber Violence Against Women and Girls
Description: In this three-part series learners focus on understanding the impact of cyber violence against women and girls
creating safer places online
knowing how to address bullying or attacks when they happen
and participating in online communities in a supportive manner.
Interest: This module was created for women and girls in emerging countries where internet adoption for women is at the utmost highest
along with a concern for security and harassment
but can be adapted for audiences everywhere.

Form Responses 1.Title: Women and Web Literacy
Description: Mozilla strives to build and support an equitable and inclusive online world for everyone. To do this
we want to challenge the existing gender imbalance that exists and create an online space where we can reach gender equality at scale.

Form Responses 1.Title: How We’re Training Women in Africa to Teach the Web
Form Responses 1.Description: A look inside Mozilla and the UN Women’s web literacy work in Nairobi and Capetown to launch  Mozilla Clubs for Women and Girls and train local leaders to teach key digital issues in a local context.

Form Responses 1.Title: Take five with Joy Chebet Bii: Why does digital literacy matter for women and girls?
Description: Joy Chebet Bii is a 20-year-old living in Nairobi
Kenya. Joy is a Mozilla Club captain teaching web literacy skills to women and girls in Nairobi. Joy uses her expertise to teach girls in Kibera
the biggest slum in Nairobi
basic coding and digital literacy skills.

Form Responses 1.Title: México has a new Mozilla Club and it starts with a leadership training for women in tech!
Description: Learn why the México Mozilla Club was created: to help
inspire
and create safe learning spaces
not only for women
but also for everyone that wants to create amazing content for the internet society.

Form Responses 1.Title: Hildah's account of a Mozilla Club for girls in Nairobi
Description: Hear from a Regional Coordinator in Nairobi giving an account to why Mozilla Clubs matters as she travels to Kariobangi
one of the slum areas in Nairobi
to see her Club Captain teach the web to young girls.
Tags: Mozilla Clubs for women and girls

Form Responses 1.Title: DeepRust
Form Responses 1.Description: We are creating a deep-learning crate (library) in rust-lang to provide a great experience to researchers & developers who are involved with developing learning algorithms and architecture for solving a machine learning problem.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Our mission is to create a crate with the best computation ability with GPU's and provide researchers with all the units of deep learning architecture.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Code contribution and fund raising

Form Responses 1.Title: MozEx
Description: Exhibition curated by the digital learning teams at the Tate and V&A museums. Showcases dynamic digital artwork that spans many disciplines & media. The exhibit explores links between art
society
and the digital world.
Interest: Exhibition catalog navigates the value of art to society through web-literacy
digital inclusion and accessibility
social action
privacy
policy
and hacking. This book is a collection of the artist' work
giving a window into the MozEx exhibit
experience and exchange.

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla Foundation Icon Font
Form Responses 1.Description: An icon font that features all of the icons from the various websites and apps maintained by the Mozilla Foundation. Also includes downloadable SVG files for each icon.
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Looking for people to try it out & leave feedback.
Form Responses 1.Suggestions & Feedback: Allow me to upload / specify a cover image for this project.

Form Responses 1.Title: Designing for MozFest
Form Responses 1.Description: Blog post sharing the design process and experience working on MozFest.

Form Responses 1.Title: Network Demos
Description: 25 Nov 2016 – Demos of our recent projects
including design
engineering
and related programs. Featuring recent participants of Open Leadership Training!
Interest: twitter crisis

Tim Head @betatim (3:20)
OpenStudentBook

Edoardo Viola @edovio (8:57)
Digital Skills Observatory

Bonface @thebonface & Alex @xelawafs (12:20)
crowdmapping

Winnie @IamProvisional (20:28)
You Look Familiar

Minn Soe (@minn_so) (23:55)
Open Data Hack
Dennis Ndegwa @dendegwa (36:00)
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Everyone is welcome to join the video call.

Form Responses 1.Title: Teaching Community Technology Handbook
Form Responses 1.Description: This 100+ page handbook will take you through the history of popular education while offering a step-by-step guide to developing community rooted technology workshops and curricula. Community Technology focuses on teaching strategies that make learning technology accessible and relevant.

Form Responses 1.Title: The Glass Room
Form Responses 1.Description: The Glass Room is a place to consider how you use technology and how those behind technology use you.
Interest: This pop-up store looks like a slick store offering shiny consumer products. It products actually reveal the dynamics of living in the Internet age. Who are we revealing when we’re online? What facts and fictions are recreated from our digital breadcrumbs? What is known about us
and why?
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Tips and resources for people who couldn't visit the pop-up store:

Form Responses 1.Title: Transvision
Form Responses 1.Description: Transvision is a specialized search engine to find localized strings of all Mozilla products and websites.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Improve translation quality of Firefox in your language
Form Responses 1.Get involved: Know PHP? Help us add new features!

Title: Maker Party Week Campinas 2016: copyright
art and learning
Description: The Maker Party this year is focused on the need for changes in copyright laws in Europe
but there are other ways to work a Maker Party in Brazil
since it is important to educate as people on copyright and open licenses.

Form Responses 1.Title: The Internet Health Report
Description: How do we measure the health of the Internet? In 2016
we laid the groundwork for a new open source effort to track the health of the Internet from year to year. The prototype for the report is launching in January 2017 (check back!).
Form Responses 1.Get involved: We will be requesting feedback on the prototype and gathering ideas for the next version in 2017.

Form Responses 1.Title: Nerdcator
Description: A basic app that allows travelers to find nearby sites of special interest to scientists and nerds such as geological/botanical features
offbeat museums
graves of our scientific heroes
locations of historic/scientific events/interest
and even research labs offering tours.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Anyone is welcome to contribute locations of interest or help us make the site better and more-fully-featured.
Get involved: Check out our CONTRIBUTING.md file to learn more
and our github contact is in the README.md file!
Suggestions & Feedback: Maybe add a guide to how to write a CONTRIBUTING file

Form Responses 1.Title: Mozilla Leadership Network 2016 Reflections Timeline
Form Responses 1.Description: An Interactive timeline featuring highlights from the Mozilla Leadership Network in 2016.
Interest: Learn more about key events
announcements
and new projects from across the MLN team in 2016.

Title: Web Literacy Leaders: Web Literacy and 21C Skills
Curriculum
Trainings
and Credentials
Creators: Cross MoFo team collaboration with IMLS
Description: A link to resources associated with making the case for web literacy and 21C skills:  research-based Web Literacy Map
curriculum
training
and credentials from 2016.  Next step for spread and contributing to Internet of Health: Grow more Web Literacy Leaders in 2017.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Co-creation of web literacy materials and making the case by cross MoFo team and partners

Form Responses 1.Title: Open Data Primers
Form Responses 1.Description: An online handbook of Open Data Training Primers developed by the Mozilla Science Lab and their community members.  These primers are designed to read at your own pace and pick and choose the topics you want to read concerning open data.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Lays out basics of open data for anyone interested in the topic and assumes no prior knowledge.
Get involved: Would love feedback on the primers so far
as well as ideas and contributions for future modules.  Create an issue at the link below.

Form Responses 1.Title: Open Data Instructor Guides
Description: This site is a resource for train-the-trainer type materials on Open Data. It's meant to provide a series of approachable
fun
collaborative workshops where each of the modules is interactive and customizable to meet a variety of audiences.
Form Responses 1.Interest: This website will help those who want to teach others about Open Data.  It has pre-packaged exercises and resources that can be remixed for different audiences.
Get involved: Would love feedback on the instructor guides so far
as well as ideas and contributions for future modules.  Create an issue at the link below.

Form Responses 1.Title: Mass Surveillance Challenge
Form Responses 1.Description: Mozilla Advocacy Network’s Surveillance Counter Narratives Project is a $350k challenge supported (in part) by the Open Society Foundations. Web-based media artists in Europe and Latin America compete to create compelling narratives that challenge mass surveillance & shift public opinion & behavior.
Form Responses 1.Interest: This effort is designed to surface and support fresh new artistic voices in web-based media.
Suggestions & Feedback:
Can you add the following to the READ MORE jump page? 

An open call for proposals will be released in early 2017. Winning artists will receive funding
and connections across the Mozilla Leadership Network.

Form Responses 1.Title: Crowd2Map
Form Responses 1.Creators:
Janet Chapman & Egle Marija Ramanauskaite
Tanzania Development Trust
crowd2maptanzania@gmail.com
Description: Emerging from MozFest 2015

Crowd2Map improves maps of rural Tanzania to support development and humanitarian efforts — with a focus on protecting girls from female genital mutilation and ensuring they get quality education and can continue to shape their own futures.
Form Responses 1.Interest: Contribute to an important global initiative while learning how an open project operates.
Get involved: People outside of Tanzania can help with satellite mapping. Locally
contributors can participate using Maps.me on their mobile phone. You can also organize a mapathon in your community or contribute coding or other skills.

Form Responses 1.Title: Heartmob
Description: Help people who are being harassed by documenting
sending support
and reporting abuse. Or
if you are being harassed online
you can develop a safety plan
document harassment
and get support.
Interest: A practical way to help people dealing with online harassment
or to get support.
Get involved: People can offer to help others
or request to receive help by  joining the Heartmob community.
